file_metadata.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]
file_metadata.title: Light-Activated Serotonin for Exploring Its Action in Biological Systems

chunks.text: Serotonin (5-HT) is a neuromodulator involved in regulating mood, appetite, memory, learning, pain, and establishing left-right (LR) asymmetry in embryonic development. Two "caged" 5-HT forms, BHQ-O-5HT and BHQ-N-5HT, were created. BHQ-O-5HT releases 5-HT upon exposure to 365 or 740 nm light through one- or two-photon excitation, respectively. BHQ-O-5HT mediated changes in neural activity in cultured mouse primary sensory neurons and the trigeminal ganglion and optic tectum of intact zebrafish larvae. In Xenopus laevis embryos, light-activated 5-HT increased LR patterning defects, with maximal rates observed at stage 5 compared with stage 8.
chunks.chunk_summary: Caged serotonin compounds enable light-controlled release of 5-HT, affecting neural activity and LR patterning in model organisms.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: Serotonin (5-HT) is a biogenic amine found in various eukaryotes. In vertebrates, it acts as a neurotransmitter and hormone, influencing mood, appetite, memory, learning, and pain. 5-HT is involved in embryonic development and LR asymmetry. Mammals have 14 5-HT receptor subtypes grouped into seven families (5-HT1-7). 5-HT3 receptors are ligand-gated ion channels mediating fast synaptic transmission, while the others are G protein-coupled receptors. Several drugs target these 5-HT signaling systems.
chunks.chunk_summary: Serotonin is a versatile signaling molecule with diverse roles in physiology and development, acting through a variety of receptor subtypes.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: Light-activated 5-HT is useful for studying its physiological roles. Caging 5-HT with a photoremovable protecting group (PPG) allows its controlled release upon light exposure. Ideal caged 5-HT should be light-sensitive at biocompatible wavelengths, release 5-HT rapidly and quantitatively, have no off-target effects, and be stable in the dark. Two-photon excitation (2PE) sensitivity is desirable for subcellular localization. Existing caged 5-HTs have limitations in photolysis efficiency, molar absorptivity, and release kinetics. This study reports two BHQ-protected 5-HT compounds (BHQ-O-5HT and BHQ-N-5HT) and their use for controlling 5-HT release.
chunks.chunk_summary: Caging serotonin with a photoremovable protecting group allows for controlled release upon light exposure, and this study introduces two new BHQ-protected compounds.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: BHQ was chosen as the caging group for its sensitivity to 1PE at biocompatible wavelengths and rapid release kinetics.  High light sensitivity is important for thick or pigmented tissues. Rapid kinetics is crucial for studying fast signaling events and 2PE. BHQ's moderate 2PE sensitivity and rapid kinetics could be advantageous. Phenols and alcohols typically require a carbonate linker for efficient release, but the decarboxylation step is slow. Direct phenol release is preferable. BHQ-OPh was synthesized and tested, showing stability and good photolysis properties, demonstrating the feasibility of phenol release from BHQ.
chunks.chunk_summary: BHQ is a suitable caging group due to its light sensitivity, rapid release kinetics, and ability to release phenol directly.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: Two versions of photoactivatable 5-HT were prepared: BHQ-O-5HT (ether linkage) and BHQ-N-5HT (carbamate linker). BHQ-O-5HT was synthesized via mesylate displacement and deprotection. BHQ-N-5HT was synthesized using carbonyldiimidazole activation and TIPS-protected serotonin, followed by deprotection. Photophysical and photochemical properties were examined and compared with existing caged 5-HTs. BHQ-protected 5-HTs showed higher absorbance maxima, molar absorptivities, and quantum efficiencies than CNB-, NPE-, and Ru(bpy)2-protected 5-HTs. BHQ-O-5HT was the most sensitive at 368 nm. Both were stable in the dark.
chunks.chunk_summary: Two BHQ-protected 5-HT compounds were synthesized and exhibited superior photochemical properties compared to existing caged 5-HTs.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: BHQ-N-5HT may be less useful for 2PE or activating ionotropic 5-HT receptors due to slow 5-HT release. Carbamic acid intermediates decompose slowly (6-7 ms), slower than diffusion from the 2PE focal volume (113-900 μs) and ion channel opening (1-2 ms). BHQ-O-5HT releases 5-HT on nanosecond timescales, much faster than diffusion.
chunks.chunk_summary: BHQ-N-5HT's slow release kinetics limits its use for 2PE and ionotropic receptor activation, while BHQ-O-5HT's rapid release is advantageous.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: BHQ-O-5HT's effects on neural activity were tested using extracellular recordings from mouse DRG neurons and zebrafish trigeminal ganglion and optic tectum. 5-HT depolarized most DRG neurons, while some showed a hyperpolarization-activated cation current. BHQ-O-5HT elicited similar responses only after photolysis.  BHQ-OH and solvent had no effect. In zebrafish, BHQ-O-5HT induced neural activity only after photolysis. Repeated light exposure resulted in repeated activity, but with diminishing intensity. BHQ-OH and light alone had no effect. BHQ-O-5HT showed low toxicity in both models.
chunks.chunk_summary: BHQ-O-5HT successfully modulated neural activity in both cultured mouse neurons and intact zebrafish larvae upon photolysis, demonstrating its biological efficacy.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: BHQ-O-5HT's physiological action was assayed in Xenopus embryos using LR patterning as an endpoint. Soaking embryos in BHQ-O-5HT did not cause LR defects, indicating it doesn't penetrate the cell membrane. Injecting BHQ-O-5HT and uncaging 5-HT caused LR defects similar to 5-HT injection. Uncaging at stage 5 produced significant LR defects, while uncaging at stage 8 had less effect. BHQ-O-5HT showed low toxicity. BHQ-N-5HT did not disrupt LR patterning, possibly due to light penetration issues.
chunks.chunk_summary: BHQ-O-5HT, when injected and uncaged, disrupted LR patterning in Xenopus embryos, particularly at stage 5, demonstrating its physiological activity.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: BHQ-protected 5-HTs have higher quantum efficiencies and 2PE cross-sections than previously reported caged 5-HTs. BHQ-O-5HT is more light-sensitive and has faster release kinetics. It effectively depolarized neurons in culture and in zebrafish larvae. Light-induced 5-HT release disrupted LR patterning in Xenopus embryos, maximally at stage 5. These experiments demonstrate BHQ-caged 5-HT's potential for studying 5-HT's physiological role, especially in whole animal studies.
chunks.chunk_summary: BHQ-caged 5-HT, particularly BHQ-O-5HT, offers improved photochemical properties and demonstrated biological activity, making it a valuable tool for studying 5-HT physiology.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: BHQ-caged 5-HT could be used to study neural activity propagation, seizures, epilepsy, mood, appetite, memory, learning, and cognitive functions. It can also be used to explore 5-HT's role in developmental patterning events like LR patterning and melanocyte differentiation. BHQ-caged 5-HT is relatively nontoxic, has little leakage, and can be released using standard equipment, enabling better investigation of 5-HT signaling pathways in the brain and development.
chunks.chunk_summary: BHQ-caged 5-HT offers a powerful tool for investigating diverse 5-HT-mediated processes in the brain and during development due to its spatiotemporal control and low toxicity.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: Dissociated mouse DRG neurons were plated and mounted in a perfusion chamber. 5-HT, BHQ-O-5HT, or BHQ-OH solutions were pressure ejected near the neurons. Flash photolysis was performed using a Cairn Flash Photolysis System with a 365 nm filter. Extracellular recordings were made using glass microelectrodes.  Electrical activity was recorded, filtered, and digitized. Experiments were conducted in dark room conditions at room temperature.
chunks.chunk_summary: Extracellular recordings were used to measure the effects of 5-HT, BHQ-O-5HT, and BHQ-OH on dissociated mouse DRG neurons under controlled light conditions.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: DRG neurons were exposed to BHQ-O-5HT and incubated in the dark. Viable cell counts were made using trypan blue. The percentage of dead cells was determined.
chunks.chunk_summary: Trypan blue exclusion assay was used to assess the toxicity of BHQ-O-5HT on cultured DRG neurons.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: 5 dpf zebrafish larvae were immobilized and mounted in agarose. Solutions of 5-HT, BHQ-O-5HT, or BHQ-OH were microinjected near the maxillary nerve. Electrical activity was monitored with a field electrode placed on the trigeminal ganglion. Flash photolysis and electrical activity recording were performed as described for DRG neurons. Experiments were conducted in dark room conditions at room temperature.
chunks.chunk_summary: The effects of 5-HT, BHQ-O-5HT, and BHQ-OH on neural activity in zebrafish larvae were assessed by microinjection and electrophysiological recordings under controlled light conditions.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: Zebrafish larvae mortality and cell death at the injection site were assessed to determine BHQ-O-5HT toxicity. Cell death was assessed by microscopy and/or acridine orange staining.
chunks.chunk_summary: Mortality and cell death at the injection site were used to assess the toxicity of BHQ-O-5HT in zebrafish larvae.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: Xenopus embryos were collected, fertilized, and staged according to standard protocols.  All procedures were approved by Tufts University's Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee.
chunks.chunk_summary: Standard protocols were followed for the collection, fertilization, and staging of Xenopus embryos, with ethical approval obtained.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: Single-cell Xenopus embryos were injected with 5-HT, BHQ-O-5HT, or BHQ-OH in the animal pole under a red lamp. After injection, embryos were washed and incubated in the dark at 18°C.
chunks.chunk_summary: Xenopus embryos were microinjected with 5-HT, BHQ-O-5HT, or BHQ-OH under a red lamp to prevent premature uncaging.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: Single-cell Xenopus embryos were soaked in 5-HT or BHQ-O-5HT solutions, washed at stage 5 or 8, and incubated in the dark at 18°C.
chunks.chunk_summary: Xenopus embryos were soaked in 5-HT or BHQ-O-5HT solutions and then washed and incubated in the dark.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]

chunks.text: After soaking or injection with BHQ-O-5HT, embryos were exposed to light to uncage 5-HT. LR patterning was assessed at stage 45 by inspecting the heart, stomach, and gall bladder.
chunks.chunk_summary: 5-HT was uncaged from BHQ-O-5HT by light exposure, and LR patterning was assessed in Xenopus embryos.
chunks.authors: ["Adam R. E. Loa", "Laura N. Vandenberg", "Rebecca E. Ball", "Ashley A. Snouffer", "Alicia G. Hudson", "Yue Zhu", "Duncan C. McLain", "Lindsey L. Johnston", "James L. Lauderdale", "Michael Levin", "Timothy M. Dore"]
